facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 304 of 1962 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 304 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated December 1, 1958 of Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 270 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 1, 1958, of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 270 of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by SHAH J. on April 15, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. April 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.--

facts.text: On October 18, 1954, District Board Agra resolved to terminate appellant's employment as Engineer by giving three months salary in lieu of notice.

anchor.surface_text: On October 18, 1954, the District Board, Agra resolved to terminate after giving salary for three months in lieu of numberice, the employment of the appellant who held the office of Engineer under the Board,

facts.text: Intimation of termination given to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: and intimation in that behalf was given to him.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Government of U.P. against termination order, dismissed on December 5, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal perferred by the appellant to the Government of U. P. against the order terminating his employment was dismissed on December 5, 1956.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 in Allahabad High Court for certiorari quashing Board's resolution of October 18, 1954 and State's order of December 5, 1956, and mandamus to treat him as lawfully appointed Engineer.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then submitted a petition to the High Court of Allahabad under Art. ?26 of the Constitution for a writ in the nature of certiorari quashing the resolution passed by the Board on October 18, 1954, and the order dated December 5, 1956, passed by the State of U.P. dismissing the appellants appeal, and a writ in the nature of mandamus companymanding the Board and the State of U.P. to treat the appellant as the lawfully appointed Engineer of the District Board and number to give effect to the resolution terminating the services of the appellant passed by the Board on October 18, 1954.

facts.text: Appellant averred flawless service but annoyed Tota Ram and President, honest and faithful, capriciously terminated.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant averred that he had as Engineer of the Board rendered flawless service but a member of the Board named Tota Ram felt annoyed with him for reasons which had numberhing to do with the proper discharge of his duties as an Engineer,, and the President of the District Board was number very happy with the appellant for reasons best known to the President, that he had spent the best part of his life in the service of the District Board and even though he has been honest and faithfull in the discharge of his duties the District Board, has capriciously and without any justification terminated his services,

facts.text: Board's affidavit: appellant guilty of negligence and unfaithfulness, censured, increments stopped, once dismissed then rescinded.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the Board an affidavit was filed stating that the appellant was guilty of negligence, and unfaithfulness , and he was censured, his annual increments were stopped, and that he was once dismissed and thereafter the resolution of dismissal was rescinded.

facts.text: Affidavit catalogued several incidents supporting negligence.

anchor.surface_text: The affidavit catalogued serveral incidents in support of this case,

facts.text: State of U.P. submitted termination per rule 3A iv, no appeal lay, rejection correct.

anchor.surface_text: The State of U.P. submitted that the services of the appellant were terminated in accordance with rule 3 A iv  of the District Board Manual, that numberappeal lay against the. resolution terminating the services of the appellant under rule 3 A  iv  of the Rules regarding Officers and Servants of District Boards and that the order of the State Government rejecting the appeal was companyrect.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the writ petition holding Board had power under fourth proviso to s.82 to terminate employment per rule 3A cl.iv unless by way of punishment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the petition holding that under the fourth proviso to s. 82 of the District Boards Act, 1922, the Board had the power to appoint and to determine the employment of an Engineer of the Board and unless the determination was by way of punishment it companyld be made in the manner provided by rule 3A cl.  iv  after giving numberice of three months or a sum equal to salary for three months in lieu of numberice.

facts.text: High Court rejected contention that power to dismiss only for punishing delinquent after procedure.

anchor.surface_text: The Court rejected the companytention of the appellant that the power to dismiss companyferred by the fourth proviso to s.82, companyld only be exercised for punishing a delinquent servant of the Board and after following the procedure prescribed in that behalf, and that apart from the power to dismiss, there was numberpower vested under the Act to determine employment and companysequently the provisions of rule 3 A cl.  iv  were ineffective.

facts.text: Appeal preferred to Supreme Court with certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the High Court this appeal is preferred with certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant censured for neglect of duty on March 25, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant pointed out that in the affidavit filed on behalf of the Board, the entire service- sheet of the appellant since the year 1945 was set out. The affidavit refers to the censure administered to the appellant for neglect of duty on March 25, 1945,

facts.text: Appellant dismissed in 1946 for negligence and unfaithfulness, resolution rescinded.

anchor.surface_text: to the order of dismissal of the appellant from service on a finding by the Public Works Committee that he was guilty of negligence and unfaithfulness in 1946, to the companyments made by the Chairman of the Board in 1947

facts.text: Annual increments stopped by President in 1953 and 1954.

anchor.surface_text: to stoppage of increments of the appellant by an order of the President of the Board in 1953 and 1954.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Board had power to determine employment under s.82 and rules, not dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the Board had the power to determine the employment of the appellant and the Board purported to exercise that power.

facts.text: Supreme Court refused to consider if termination was camouflage for dismissal as not pleaded or argued in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore refuse tO companysider the question whether the order passed against the appellant pursuant to the resolution dated October 18, 1954 was for dismissal of the appellant from the service of the Board, as a punishment for misconduct.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The .appeal therefore fails and is dismissed.

issues.text: Whether the jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution is restricted by s. 21(b) of the Specific Relief Act in granting relief declaring unlawful termination of employment by a statutory body like the District Board

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Board contended in limine that the appellant number being a member of the civil service of the State was number entitled to the protection of Art. 311 of the Constitution, and the relief claimed by him being in substance one for an order restoring him to the service of the Board, from which he was dismissed, the jurisdiction of the High Court even under Art. 226 of the Constitution was restricted by s. 21  b  of the Specific Relief Act

issues.text: Whether under the District Boards Act, 1922 the Board is invested with the power to determine employment of a servant of the Board otherwise than by way of dismissal as punishment

anchor.surface_text: The question which then falls to be determined is whether under the District Boards Act, 1922 the Board is invested with the power to determine employment of a servant of the Board otherwise than by way of dismissal as punishment, and for that purpose certain provisions of the Act and the rules framed under the Act may usefully be referred.

issues.text: Whether the expression 'dismissal' in the fourth proviso to s. 82 of the District Boards Act includes termination of employment simpliciter

anchor.surface_text: We are however unable to agree with the High Court that the expression dismissal in the fourth proviso to s. 82 includes termination of employment simpliciter. In the law relating to master and servant the expression dismissal has acquired a limited meaning- determination of employment as a method of punishment for misconduct or other cause.

issues.text: Whether the Board's resolution terminating the appellant's employment was in reality a punitive dismissal camouflaged as termination simpliciter

anchor.surface_text: It is settled law that the form of the order under which the employment of a servant is determined is number conclusive of the true nature of the order. The form may be merely to camouflage an order of dismissal for misconduct, and it is always open to the court before which the order is challenged to go behind the form and ascertain the true character of the order.

issues.text: Whether the termination of the appellant's services was in accordance with rule 3A(iv) of the District Board Rules and no appeal lay against it

anchor.surface_text: The State of U.P. submitted that the services of the appellant were terminated in accordance with rule 3 A iv  of the District Board Manual, that number appeal lay against the. resolution terminating the services of the appellant under rule 3 A  iv  of the Rules regarding Officers and Servants of District Boards and that the order of the State Government rejecting the appeal was correct.

anchor.surface_text: The other material rule framed by Notification issued by the Government of U.P. dated March 25, 1946, is headed Regulation regarding dismissal, removal or reduction of officers and servants of District Boards.

holdings.text: The contention raised by the counsel for the Board that a petition for a declaration that the employment of the appellant was not lawfully terminated and on that account the Board be commanded to treat the appellant as lawfully in service cannot be maintained, must be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The contention raised by the counsel for the Board that a petition for a declaration that the employment of the appellant was number lawfully terminated. and on that account the Board be companymanded to treat the appellant as lawfully in service cannot be maintained, must be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished precedents like Shahjahanpur, Ram Babu, Dutt as not involving statutory invalidity; courts can declare ultra vires acts of statutory bodies even if compelling retention, citing Vina v National Dock Labour Board.

holdings.text: The 1946 notification is a rule framed under s.172 of the District Boards Act, not a regulation under s.173.

anchor.surface_text: Even though this is designated a regulation it is conceded, and in our judgment rightly, by the Board and the State of P. that it is a rule framed in exercise of the powers conferred by s. 172

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act confers no power under s.173 cl.2 for regulations on dismissal; conceded by parties and judgment concurs as under rule-making power s.172.

holdings.text: The expression 'dismissal' in the fourth proviso to s.82 does not include termination of employment simpliciter.

anchor.surface_text: We are however unable to agree with the High Court that the expression dismissal in the fourth proviso to s. 82 includes termination of employment simpliciter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismissal has acquired punitive meaning in service law; supported by appeal rights in s.82 provisos indicating punishment; separate rules for punitive dismissal vs rule 3A simpliciter.

holdings.text: The Board had the power to determine the employment of the appellant otherwise than by dismissal as punishment, and purported to exercise that power in accordance with rule 3A.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the Board had the power to determine the employment of the appellant and the Board purported to exercise that power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power from s.82 (service matters, appoint), subject to s.84 rules; power to appoint includes terminate per doctrine; rule 3A prescribes method for simpliciter termination by competent authority (Board).

holdings.text: Refuse to consider whether the termination order was camouflage for punitive dismissal as not pleaded or argued before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore refuse tO consider the question whether the order passed against the appellant pursuant to the resolution dated October 18, 1954 was for dismissal of the appellant from the service of the Board, as a punishment for misconduct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: New factual case not raised in pleadings or High Court arguments; would surprise respondent; primarily factual inquiry requiring evidence.

holdings.text: The termination was in accordance with rule 3A(iv); no appeal lay against it.

anchor.surface_text: The Board by its resolution dated October 18, 1954, purported to exercise the power of determination in the manner and subject to conditions prescribed by rule 3A. The determination was by resolution of the Board and prima facie, that exercise of the power may be effective.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resolution gave 3 months pay in lieu; by Board (competent to appoint); complies with rule 3A cl.iv for permanent servants.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the Court would be justified in granting a declaration about the invalidity of the action of a statutory body terminating the employment of a servant was raised before the House of Lords in Vina v. National Dock Labour Board 1 . L. R. 1957 A.C. 488.

precedents.case_name: Vina v National Dock Labour Board
precedents.cited_proposition: Court can declare ultra vires termination of employment by statutory body even if it compels retention
